verses.text: Working together with Him, we urge you not to receive God’s grace in vain.
verses.comment: Paul continues the previous appeals, stressing cooperation with God and the importance of human response to grace. It implies that grace may be given, yet ineffectual if not embraced and acted upon (see Rom. 3:24).

verses.text: For He says, 'At the acceptable time I listened to you, and in the day of salvation I helped you.' Look, now is the acceptable time; now is the day of salvation.
verses.comment: Paul cites Isaiah 49:8 about God's readiness to save. The urgency of 'now' highlights the present opportunity to receive salvation, connecting prophecy to its fulfillment in Christ's work. Paul urges immediate response to the Gospel (see Rom. 13:11).

verses.text: We put no obstacle in anyone’s way, so that our ministry will not be blamed.
verses.comment: Paul stresses the integrity of his ministry, ensuring it remains above reproach. This reflects the apostolic commitment to holiness and blameless service (see 1Tim. 3:7).

verses.text: Rather, in everything we commend ourselves as servants of God: in great endurance, in afflictions, in hardships, in distresses,
verses.comment: Listing aspects of apostolic suffering, Paul demonstrates that true ministry is marked by perseverance in adversity (see 2Cor. 11:23-28). The word 'servants' carries strong connotations of self-sacrifice, recalling Christ’s own example.

verses.text: in beatings, in imprisonments, in riots, in labors, in sleepless nights, in times of hunger;
verses.comment: Paul summarizes the physical suffering he and his fellow ministers endure for the sake of the Gospel, echoing the suffering of Christ for His body (see Acts 16:22-23; 2Cor. 11:27).

verses.text: in purity, in knowledge, in patience, in kindness, in the Holy Spirit, in genuine love,
verses.comment: Paul emphasizes virtues, and includes the Holy Spirit as the source of grace. Genuine love points to the authentic charity that models Jesus, reflecting the indwelling of the Spirit (see Gal. 5:22).

verses.text: in the word of truth and the power of God; with the weapons of righteousness in the right hand and in the left;
verses.comment: Paul brings together preaching and spiritual fortitude as key features of ministry. ‘Weapons of righteousness’ recall spiritual armor imagery (see Eph. 6:13-17), showing the importance of God’s power for victory over evil.

verses.text: through glory and dishonor, through slander and praise. We are considered as deceivers, yet true;
verses.comment: The tension between public perception and spiritual reality marks authentic ministry. Like Christ, Paul endures misunderstanding and false accusations, yet remains faithful to truth (see Acts 28:22).

verses.text: as unknown, yet well known; as dying, and see—we live; as punished, yet not killed;
verses.comment: Paradoxical language describes the apostolic life in Christ: apparent defeat turning to spiritual victory. The mystery of suffering and resurrection life is central here (see 2Cor. 4:10-11; Ps. 118:18).

verses.text: as sorrowful yet always rejoicing, as poor yet making many rich, as having nothing yet possessing everything.
verses.comment: Christian paradox: poverty that enriches others, sorrow that is transformed into joy. This mirrors Christ’s self-giving, whose poverty enriches believers (see 2Cor. 8:9).

verses.text: We have spoken freely to you, Corinthians; our hearts are open wide.
verses.comment: Paul affirms transparency and affection in his relationship with the church, inviting reciprocal openness as a mark of authentic Christian community.

verses.text: You are not restricted by us, but you are restricted in your own affections.
verses.comment: Paul points out that any obstacles in their relationship come from the Corinthians' own hearts. The implication is a call to interior conversion and openness.

verses.text: Now, as a fair exchange—I speak as to children—open wide your hearts also.
verses.comment: Paul appeals for reciprocated love and spiritual generosity, the marks of true unity and communion within the body of believers.

verses.text: Do not be unequally yoked with unbelievers. For what partnership is there between righteousness and lawlessness? Or what fellowship does light have with darkness?
verses.comment: Drawing on Old Testament imagery (Deut. 22:10), Paul forbids compromising spiritual purity through close association with unbelief. The Church is called to holiness and separation from evil influences (see Eph. 5:7-11).

verses.text: What agreement does Christ have with Belial? Or what does a believer share with an unbeliever?
verses.comment: Belial denotes evil or worthlessness in the Old Testament (see 1Sam. 2:12); Paul’s rhetorical questions assert the absolute incompatibility between Jesus and evil, emphasizing the need for purity in the Church.

verses.text: And what agreement has the temple of God with idols? For we are the temple of the living God, just as God said: 'I will dwell in them and walk among them, and I will be their God, and they will be my people.'
verses.comment: Mixing temple imagery from the OT (Lev. 26:11-12; Ezek. 37:27), Paul identifies believers as God’s dwelling, echoing New Covenant promises. This supports eucharistic and sacramental theology regarding God’s intimate presence amongst His people.

verses.text: 'Therefore, come out from among them and be separate,' says the Lord. 'Touch no unclean thing, and I will receive you.'
verses.comment: Quoting Isa. 52:11, Paul reinforces the call to holiness, reflecting Old Testament demands for separation from impurity, now intensified in the community united to Christ.

verses.text: 'And I will be a father to you, and you shall be my sons and daughters,' says the Lord Almighty.
verses.comment: Adoption as children of God fulfills Old Testament types (2Sam. 7:14; Isa. 43:6), realized now in Christ (see John 1:12). The promise points to the intimate family relationship offered to believers, culminating in union with God through participation in His life.
